frameDefinitions: An Item is in a state of wetness with the possibility of the wetting Liquid being mentioned, along with the Degree of wetness. '
This frame contains words describing physical experiences that can affect virtually any part of the body.
A Protagonist delays a planned action because they cannot or do not want to proceed until an Expected_event occurs.
This  frame covers the descriptions of tastes and smells, and has one main frame element, Source.
An Agent or a Cause causes a Fluid to move from a Source to a Goal along a Path or within an Area.
Words in this frame name medical conditions or diseases that a patient suffers from, is being treated for, may be cured of, or die of.
frameExamples: The mop is <t>drenched</t> with water from last night's rain.
The cat <t>waited</t> on top of the washer as Elmer popped the lid off the can of cat food and then pounded the can's contents onto the plate
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Item</fen> takes up the <fen>Liquid</fen> through its pores.
The <fen>Liquid</fen> is a fluid or gas that permeates the <fen>Item</fen>.  It most frequently occurs in a PP Complement headed by with.

The Experiencer is the being who has a physical experience on some part of his  or her body, or internally. Often information about this frame element is incorporated as a possessive determiner into the constituent expressing the Body Part, in which case it is not tagged separately (from Body Part), as shown below: My legs <t>hurt</t>! Sometimes, however, this frame element is expressed as an External Argument in its own right:  <fex name='Experiencer'>I</fex> <t>hurt</t> all over! Here, the phrase <ment>all over</ment> can be considered a kind of generalized Body Part expression, and the pronoun <ment>I</ment> expresses the Experiencer independently. With nouns and adjectives in this frame, the separate expression of the Experiencer is more common: <fex name='Experiencer'>I</fex> have a <t>pain</t> in my leg.

This role is the location on the body where the physical experience takes place, typically expressed as External Argument, often as PP complement: <fex name='Body_part'>My legs</fex> are a little <t>sore</t>. I'm a little <t>sore</t> <fex name='Body_part'>in my legs</fex>.
The sentient being who cannot proceed with their planned activities until a Salient_entity has arrived or an Expected_event has occurred.
A concrete or abstract entity that the <fen>Protagonist</fen> expects to participate in an <fen>Expected_event</fen>, typically that of arriving at the <fen>Place</fen> of the <fen>Protagonist</fen>.
The <fen>Expected_event</fen> is an event that needs to take place or a state that needs to begin to hold before the <fen>Protagonist</fen> can proceed with their planned activities.
The time period during which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.
The location in which the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is waiting.
<fen>Perceptual_source</fen> is used for the entity that is being described. A recipe can stand in for a <fen>Perceptual_source</fen> which is a kind of food.
<fen>Sensory_attribute</fen> is used for words that describe the perception itself.
The animate protagonist who causes the <fen>Fluid</fen> to move.
An event or force that causes the <fen>Fluid</fen> to move.
The entity that changes location and moves in a fluidic way. It is not necessarily in a liquid state but is construed that way.
The location that the <fen>Fluid</fen> occupies initially.
<fen>Goal</fen> is the location the <fen>Fluid</fen> ends up in as a result  of the motion
The trajectory along which the Fluid moves, exclusive of the <fen>Source</fen> and <fen>Goal</fen>.
The setting in which the <fen>Fluid</fen>'s movement takes place along an unspecified <fen>Path</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the fluidic motion event is caused.
The location where the motion takes place.
This role is used for the patient, entity, or population (originally) affected by the condition or illness.
FN: Any medical problem.
The location where the <fen>Ailment</fen> is effecting the <fen>Patient</fen>s.
listRoleExamples: The mop was drenched <fex> with water</fex>.
<fex>He</fex> politely waited, hat in hand, until he could speak.
In busier times several passengers are waiting <fex>for the train</fex>.
She did n't wait <fex>for a reply</fex>, but spelled out the answer herself.
At least 17 ships were waiting <fex>yesterday</fex> to come up the river.
Reporters are waiting <fex>outside the State Guesthouse</fex> for the talks to start .
The almonds had a bitter <fex> taste</fex>.
What happens if <fex>we</fex> drip acid on this compound?
Why did  you squirt juice <fex>onto my chair</fex>?
I spattered the egg all over the floor <fex>in the kitchen</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: "The Nigeria Police in Transition: issues, problems and prospects"
